Authors: Joshua R. McDill, Beryl B. Simpson, J. Andrew McDonald
Title:
A phylogenetic assessment of breeding system and floral
morphology in North American Ipomoea (Convolvulaceae).
Journal: Journal of the Botanical Research Institute of Texas
Abstract:
Although numerous studies on the evolution of autogamy in
angiosperms infer this breeding behavior is normally a derived feature
and usually correlated with a suite of floral traits that economize
pollen transfer, this is the first investigation to examine the
evolution of these traits using statistical analyses in a phylogenetic
context. Phylogenetic investigations of 70 taxa (68 spp. + 2 vars.) of
tropical and temperate North American Ipomoea (Convolvulaceae) using
sequence data from the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) with
parsimony and Bayesian analyses reveal multiple origins of autogamy.
Based on breeding and morphological studies, we estimate that North
American species with xenogamous breeding systems outnumber species with
inbreeding systems by a factor of five. Parsimony and likelihood
reconstructions indicate that Ipomoea was ancestrally xenogamous. We
estimate 16 independent origins of autogamy and 4 subsequent reversions
to xenogamy. Comparative analyses indicate that breeding system
transitions correlate strongly with changes in floral traits.
Transitions to autogamy are associated with reduced flower size,
decreased anther-stigma distance and reduced pollen-ovule ratios.
